snippet: Nassau County in New York used a tobacco settlement to plug the holes in its budget by winning over investors who otherwise considered it a bad credit risk.
abstract: Nassau County, NY, used a tobacco bond settlement to plug the holes in its budget by winning over bond investors who otherwise considered it a bad credit risk; Nassau projected that from 2000 to 2011, the settlement would produce $300 million to cover its bonds, but it has received $38 million less. (M)
lead_paragraph: The hundreds of millions of dollars in tobacco bonds issued by Nassau County, N.Y., illustrate both the perils in forecasting tobacco cash flows over decades and a reluctance to use the money for its original intent. When state attorneys general sued big tobacco companies in the 1990s, they made the case that smoke-related illnesses were swamping their Medicaid programs and that the companies should reimburse them and pay for programs to help smokers quit.

headline.main: Settlement Money Patched Nassau County Budget Gaps
